Review of federal tax revenue data: The expert analyzed the federal tax revenue data for the relevant time period to determine if there was an actual increase in tax revenues as claimed. They found that tax revenues only rose by 0.4 percent, which is smaller than previous years and even declined when adjusted for inflation.
Examination of the Committee for a Respo: s findings: The expert considered the analysis conducted by the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, which found that the small increase in tax revenues disappeared when other factors were taken into account. The group concluded that tax revenues actually fell by 1.6 percent when adjusted for inflation.
Assessment of tax revenues as a percenta: The expert evaluated the percentage of tax revenues in relation to the gross domestic product (GDP) to determine if economic growth had a proportional impact on tax revenues. They found that this measure fell by 4.1 percent over the first 11 months of the fiscal year, indicating that GDP growth did not boost tax revenues proportionately.
Comparison with Congressional Budget Off: The expert compared the actual tax collections to the projections made by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) before the tax law was passed. The CBO projected $3.531 trillion in tax collections based on various factors. However, the expert found that tax revenue fell short of this projection by 5.7 percent, indicating that the claim of increased tax revenues was not supported by the CBO's expectations.
